displayed_text: Patient: Is it? Doctor: I may need to give you medicine to help control it. Like Imodium and things like that. Patient: Yeah, well then, okay. ‘Cuz, yeah, I’m taking the stool softener a day thinking that, that, that, you know? And then it be like watery. Doctor: Mmm, hmm. Patient: Yeah. It be like, it be like water. Doctor: Okay. Yeah, I think I’m going to give you medication. That way, when you’re out and about and all that, you can take that, and that won’t make you go so fast. Patient: Man. Man, that was so bad, so bad. Doctor: So, Patient: I did it twice on myself, man. ‘Cuz I went out, and I had to catch the bus back home. Man, it’s like I had to walk home ‘cuz I didn’t want to get on the bus. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: They’ll be saying, “What’s that smell like shit.” Doctor: Hmm.

Patient: I can live with it if I can do the infusion stuff up there. Doctor: Okay. That's a possibility. However, as anything else, we actually have a study. Half the group gets regular chemo, which is IV. The other group gets a pill chemo which is oral. I can't tell you which one you are. And of course, we need you to commit so that if you say there's no freakin way I'm gonna get chemo down here then don't do the trial, but it's a fifty-fifty Family Member: You don't want to come down here xxx do you? Patient: How often do I have to be here? Doctor: Well, chemo is once every three weeks. So if you're good, don't quote me because I botched up a thousand things today in terms of the schedule, which is why I keep my mouth shut half the time. But standard chemo is once every three weeks. Family Member: Oh that’s not too bad. Doctor: Yeah it’s not too bad. And the pill you take, there's a funky schedule but normally it's like, twice a day. But not every day. And there's a set schedule. You don't have to be here every day for that. But I think the follow up there is once every four weeks if I'm not wrong. Family Member: The pill isn't in the container? He has to come down here? Doctor: Well, we give it to you. But it's a funky formulation where, because you know, we do an oral formulation of the chemo is a challenge. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So this is like, there's a loading dose and then you have a little bit of another dose. So it's like, it's a pharma-pharmaco kinetics dream, who thought about it, which is not like a doctor dream, which is like, “just give me the pill in my pocket once a day.” I think eventually they're going to do that. But there is a funky schedule to it. None of which you have to be here, you know, the entire time. But I think in the first few- oh gosh, the first few days I think that you're here maybe for the first week every day. So, but I'll get the schedule right, but once you get on a flow, you're not here every day. Not even close. So it’s either once every three weeks, or once every four weeks. Patient: I can do it because obviously the Xtandi has run its course.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then, you know, how do you make decisions? Huh, you know, I think it was, was it your daughter? Who was with you? Your wife? Patient: My niece. Niece. Doctor: Okay. Huh, huh, if she’s one of the people you make decisions with or other family members, huh, you can talk to them about what it is. Huh, but, huh, we’d love to have that conversation, huh, so we can go ahead, and I’ll print it for you today. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’ll stop your abiraterone. Stay on the prednisone. I’ll check insurance clearance. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, I’ll bring you back in a month no matter what. Huh, if you’re interested and you have insurance clearance, I may ask the nurse just to give you a call at home. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And say, hey, uh, it seems good. If you’re interested, you can come in this week and then we can get things started. Patient: Okay.

Patient: The - The Casodex I don’t – don’t take the Casodex? Doctor: Do you have enough for the next month or so? Patient: Right now I have about, I probably got about a week left of that before they re… Doctor: Okay perfect. Don’t refill it. Patient: Okay, but just take… Doctor: Until I figure this out. Patient: But just take the rest of those? Doctor: And then I’ll have you come back next week. Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. (pause doctor whispering) Patient: So finish these off and don’t refill. Doctor: Right. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But we’ll be talking to you within the next few days and seeing if we have to alter the plans at all. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: So what you think my tests might be? Doctor: Yeah. We’ll find out by tomorrow. Patient: Okay, that’ll be good. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Thank you. Doctor: You’re welcome. Patient: Nice seeing you again. Doctor: Do you have any questions? Patient: Um no. I’m I’m good.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You just can’t overdo it or you’re gonna be in the hospital between here and F___. You just got to be careful. Even if you end up in the hospital you just call me and I’ll work with your docs. It will be fine. Okay. So just get rest on the road. Patient: Oh yeah, oh yeah. Doctor: Okay. Alright. Patient: I mean you know I ain’t stupid. Doctor: Hi. Healthcare Professional: Hi. Patient: Get it done. Come on C__, come on over here. Doctor: She’s out of here. Patient: You know what man. Doctor: Here’s your starter kit. Patient: What is this?. Doctor: There’s some information for you about what this medicine is. And this medicine so see… no wait (pages turning)

Family Member 1: Let's go to the kitchen, not the bathroom. Patient: Yeah, I won't be doing that. Doctor: Yeah, I think it you know, it's always hard. Patient: I don’t want to get too much involved. Doctor: I mean, the easiest way to get Patient: I just won’t go there. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, good idea. Doctor: I just wont go there. Healthcare Professional: How old is she? Family Member 1: Yeah but the Mother is. Doctor: Yeah, but they’re always into things and we talked about this. Family Member 1: She’s not out of her first trimester. Yeah.

Patient: Right. Doctor: and go through that. Family Member: So tomorrow at ten o’clock even if he has, he’s going to see the urologist, should we send you or will you be in touch with them or how? Doctor: We’ve been getting the notes from whoever you see. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: My sense is you guys are great communicators, that you know you have the catheters out, the catheter is not out. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And those are all sorts of things that again that again you’re going to probably need a face-to-face visit with D___ as you come back and so that will be also the time to update you as well. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And again, Dr. ___ was going to want to see you today because he enjoys working with you as well – Patient: Good.

Family Member: Hormones - Uh is he getting more medicine today? Doctor: Well he got that shot; that shot lasts for three months Family Member: OHH! Patient: For three months? Oh, okay. I thought it was for three weeks. Doctor: Three months. Patient: Three months. Family Member: Three months. So at what point does the prostate shrink? Doctor: That’s our hope. Family Member: OHH! Patient: So should I be wearing this catheter for a while then? Doctor: Well because again it could be as early as this week that they feel like you can pee on your own. But if that’s what they’re going to be testing - Patient: And they cannot test it any other way except by pulling it out.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Your potassium two times a day? Patient: Right. Doctor: Prednisone one pill twice a day? Patient: Right. Doctor: So that’s what I have. Anything else you’re taking that I don’t know about? Patient: No. You’ve got it all. Doctor: So I’m going to put Bell’s palsy on here. You said it’s lopsided? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And you’ve had, not had any issues with depression in the past or anxiety? Patient: No. Doctor: Any acid reflux?

Patient: <___> what I’m sayin’. Doctor: Right. To try to speed this along I think I’ll refer you to Dr. L____. He’s our person here who takes care of sexual dysfunction. Patient: Um hmmm. Doctor: Uh Because uh you know it seems like that certainly is something that concerns you very much. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: And so… Patient: I do want a life you know I want someone with me you know. Doctor: I hear ya, okay. Patient: So I play dodge ball. (Laughs) Doctor: You’re not the only person. Patient: Yeah. (Laughs) Doctor: That’s like that, anyway. How’s the water passing?

Patient: I think so. Doctor: On that one? Patient: Right, but the ones do you remember… Doctor: Yeah, yeah, but those though they don’t agree with you huh? The effects are… Patient: Yeah, the ones you gave me before that I think it was for… Doctor: The Megnace. Patient: Yeah I think that was for you know for throwing up or something like that. I take them because I took them and then it always worked. Like when I be feeling like nauseous I’ll throw up, I’ll take one of them and then I I cool down. But them other ones they Doctor: They didn’t agree with you. Patient: They made me want to jump out of my skin and run up the street. Doctor: That’s too bad, yeah. That’s scary. Doctor: Okay, so let’s give him then Patient: Wooh. Healthcare Professional: So

Patient: I doubt anybody gonna give me a Social Security card, though. Doctor: Let’s see on here. Um. So, you have Lupron and Patient: I was, I was lookin’ forward to takin’ that chemo, but I wasn’t worried about it. I just wanted to see whether, see this is what I wanted to do. I wanted to take it, G_ so I could see what type of effect would it take and then I would know and Doctor: No. Not if you just had started diarrhea, like just two, three days ago again. Patient: But I don’t know, I don’t know, I don’t know if it was the chemo ‘cuz I just had it, um Doctor: No. I don’t want the chemo to aggravate anything. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: So about two to three more weeks? Doctor: Yeah. Two more weeks. So, on October fourth, you’re gonna come back. Patient: But I see you October the eleventh Doctor: You’re not

Patient: And I just wondered you know with. Doctor: Yes. Yeah I agree with you. Patient: As far as, as far as… Doctor: It’s not a trivial issue by any means. Patient: But you know like I say with the PSA if it’s up and everything but the scans the CT scans are good I mean if they’re… Doctor: Yeah, so that’s a good situation to be in is what I’ll tell you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You know then clearly me telling you you know what things are getting worse just come off this and go get… Patient: Yeah, that’s right. Doctor: Because that would be a really bad outcome overall. Patient: Yeah but it’s not like that so that’s… Doctor: Yeah, that’s a good thing. That’s why we’re having this back and forth even. Patient: Yes.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 3 years (2 years but les: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 3 years (2 years but less than 3 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Disabled: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Disabled

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: We’re all like crazy mad scientists in the back. Go, here’s what I, look, that’s what we like to do but with prostate cancer every time we do that it doesn’t behave. It either does nothing but give you more side effects or it just causes a problem. You know, like if you combine this with Zytiga you get more fractures. That’s no good. Patient: Right, I remember you saying that at one of our visits you were saying that. Doctor: Yeah and so just because theoretically like well, they should kind of work together. Patient: Right, Right. Doctor: It just doesn’t so we learned most of the drugs in prostate cancer it’s not like the other cancers where you do two or three drugs together. You know, we’re kind of like the loner group so it’s one at a time, sequence matters with one. Family Member: So this other doctor is going to explain the side effects he may get from radiation? Doctor: Yeah, so when you see Dr. B____, so that’s another Dr. B, you’re going to listen about what can or can’t you do, why is it once a month, what are your obligations. What are the potential side effects and how does he want to see you and he might need blood work kind of not on day of because there’s a half-life to the medicine as in if he knows the week before your counts are good to go then he can order it and when you show up it’s here and you get it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If he orders it and you show up and uh-oh you can’t get it, there’s, we’re in trouble. Patient: Right, Okay. Doctor: That’s fifteen thousand you might have to just flush down the toilet because you can’t save it for the next week because it starts to decay and you can’t give it to somebody else so. Patient: Okay, I’m good with that. That sounds good. Okay?
